...
 http://www.philosophersnet.com/games/god.htm
 
 Do you think you can remain logically consistent, and still hold your present beliefs about god? Play the game, see if it's not just the forums that beat you up, but logic itself.
 
 -Mach

zero direct hits and bitten 2 bullets
 
 The fact that you progressed through this activity without being hit and biting very few bullets suggests that your beliefs about God are internally consistent and well thought out.
 
 A direct hit would have occurred had you answered in a way that implied a logical contradiction. The bitten bullets occurred because you responded in ways that required that you held views that most people would have found strange, incredible or unpalatable. However, because you bit only two bullets and avoided direct hits completely you still qualify for our second highest award. A good achievement!
 
 interesting test indeed but the possibilities for answers are to limited imo.
I had two hits and bit 0 bullets. The hits were related to the Peter questions.

Seems to be pedantic about some things and not others - evolution is allowed to be essentially true yet when I say it is foolish to believe in God despite evidence, its a contradiction. 
 
 It isn't foolish to beleive in something that has no irrevocable evidence (seeing as it doesn't exist), but overwhelming evidence makes it essentially true (not some kind of ultimate truth) yet I do beleive it is foolish to beleive in god without irrevocable (just the usual evidence) evidence. I don't require more evidence, I require the same but the way its written doesn't give this option. Saying that its not foolish to believe in God despite a lack of irrevocerable evidence misses out on the fact that there is (from my point of view) no real evidence anyway. If it said purely based on the lack of irrevocable evidence, I'd agree with it..but hey, it comes under the caveat of rewording so if I cheat that one I emerge unscathed.
Interesting mental masturbation but highly flawed and pretty useless.

Congratulations!
 You have been awarded the TPM medal of distinction! This is our second highest award for outstanding service on the intellectual battleground.
 
 The fact that you progressed through this activity being hit only once and biting very few bullets suggests that your beliefs about God are well thought out and almost entirely internally consistent.
 
 
 The direct hit you suffered occurred because one set of your answers implied a logical contradiction. The bitten bullets occurred because you responded in ways that required that you held views that most people would have found strange, incredible or unpalatable. At the bottom of this page, we have reproduced the analyses of your direct hit and bitten bullets.
 
 
 Because you only suffered one direct hit and bit very few bullets, you qualify for our second highest award. A good achievement!
 
 When do I get the medal? At least send me a prayer handkerchief!

I faired poorly .2 in fact. However, the explanations provided had poorly conceptualized assumptions. They assumed that suffering in this world is inconsistent with a benevolent God. This is not necessarily true. Both can and do exist. Without suffering, without hardship, there would be no determination fo good and evil. Things simply would "be".
 
 For a "philosophy" game it is poorly thought out. It should be possible to rewrite the programming with assumptions that are more carefully defined and I do believe you would find things dramatically changed.
 
 That said, I am fine that things don't necessarily make sense to folks. I don't suppose they would. After all, a God that transcends space and time and the universe would not fit neatly within mans definitions now would he.

Was 'your god' a omnipotent creator that could do anything?
 Then its penalising you for saying the God can do anything, and then saying it can't make a world with motivation for good and evil without suffering.
 
 I personally don't think your logic is right anyway but as a guess it might have been this which its penalising you on. Its being very picky about how far omnipotence extends

Was 'your god' a omnipotent creator that could do anything?
 Then its penalising you for saying the God can do anything, and then saying it can't make a world with motivation for good and evil without suffering.
 
 I personally don't think your logic is right anyway but as a guess it might have been this which its penalising you on. Its being very picky about how far omnipotence extends

 
 You are quite correct tasty. It assumes that omnipotence means "do anything at all". When in reality it means "do anything that is consistent with God's nature.' For example, in my conception of God, He cannot lie. This would violate their definition of omnipotent. However, if we consider that It is consistent with the nature of god it violates nothing.
 
 I appreciate that you may not agree with my conception and are still willing to look at the reasonableness of the argument.
 
 EF

Well logic says one thing religion says the opposite.
 
 You dont really need any sort of quiz to find that out, however a religious persons beliefs are just that, a belief. Nothing in any reality can justify that belief, but they still believe. So what can a "believer" do? Nothing except go with the flow.

Not entirely true - as the quiz shows, within the bounds of philosophy there needs be no problem nessarily with religion in general, it just points out that if you do beleive in something you should try to aim to make it make sense to you. At the very least, it shows the rest of us annoying doubts that you don't just accept things on blind faith, while you can't explain what makes you beleive in something you have thought about it and it makes internal sense (no doublethink required).
Shazaam! I thought the results of this test would determine my Heavenly rewards! emoticon_ic

 Very interesting statement, particularly the second part, when you say "internal sense".
 
 That to me says brainwashing of a sort, if someone is brainwashed to believe in something, then through logic decides his/her beliefs dont make sense or dont add up or there simply too many contradictions in the belief, then they would question it and try to make internal sense out of it.

One of the other problems with the quiz is that assumes there is no spiritual reality that is beyond our senses. It assumes time and space are paramount. If we assume that they are not, then things get different. But they can still be discussed logically within the bounds of philosophy.
 
 go to www.dwillard.org. Dallas Willard is a philosophy professor at USC. He is also a theologian. He meshes the two together quite beautifully and very very very logically. You would be extremely hard pressed to identify fallacies in his arguments.
 
 EF
 
 PS. The website has both philosophy articles and christian articles so you can look at either or both.

This is the problem I have with some people trying to apply logic to beliefs about God. God transcends our feeble logic in some cases. That doesn't make it easier to argue with an atheist because it's hard to convince him of it.

 
 This is exactly the point I have tried to get across many times in religion (and other) threads. People just don't seem to get it. Or don't want to get it.

I took one hit and got the second-highest award. I said that if God existed he could do anything, and I said he couldn't make 1+1=72 or make a square circle. When I answered he could do anything, I meant anything possible. Making 1+1=72 or making a square circle are impossible, the second one is an oxymoron, you can't have a square circle.

This is exactly the point I have tried to get across many times in religion (and other) threads. People just don't seem to get it. Or don't want to get it.

 
 I only understand one logic and it's not feeble. If one wants to argue that faith can't be justified logically then fine. That doesn't show the limits of logic but that faith begins where logic ends. Without faith there is no apparent, obvious, inescapable reason to believe in the supernatural. As long as someone takes refuge in their faith I wouldn't think to assault them with logic. Only when they strut about and suggest I'm missing something a simpleton should grasp that I play the logic card. That's fair as I see it.

This is exactly the point I have tried to get across many times in religion (and other) threads. People just don't seem to get it. Or don't want to get it.

 But, most religions don't describe something completely beyond logic or the material rules. God is described using human terms, interacts in a vaguely rational way (far as 'magic' goes) and is generally presented as something you can get to know/understand (in a way).
 How can you have a personal relationship with anything so alien that rational logic means nothing to it, the idea of such an alien being seems completely outside everyone who seems to be have been able to experience god on some level's descriptions. Not to mention that all our interpretations of Gods will and actions are completely meaningless.
 
 This is the problem, there is nothing wrong with a god being outside the universe and logic, but trying to interact with such a being if this is the form it takes is meaningless.

 That's not a problem with the quiz, that's called being logicaly consistent. Unless of course you feel being correct is a "problem"?

 2. It's illogical to suggest you know something exists in reality, that is beyond our senses. You know all this, I'm just can't not correct it when I see it.
 
 -Mach

Evidence never came into to the quiz like that, and was actually the opposite as fundamentally there is no evidence for anything.
 Neutrinos are beyond our senses, as is dark matter. We can kind of now sense them through other things but before that did they not exist?

That's not a problem with the quiz, that's called being logicaly consistent. Unless of course you feel being correct is a "problem"?

 2. It's illogical to suggest you know something exists in reality, that is beyond our senses. You know all this, I'm just can't not correct it when I see it.
 
 -Mach

 
 Actually, I do indeed know of what you speak. I think we disagree on it though. Logic is not about the assumptions. It is a process to a conclusion. The assumptions are what one starts with. Everything, even the observable world around you, must start with assumptions. Even the idea that one plus one equals two starts with an assumption that one is representative of something. We can draw a traingle that begins with three line segments. We assume that those segments are made of an infinite number of points. A point is representative of something that must be assumed and can never be proven. It is why the concept "any two points can make a line" is stated as a "postulate" and not a law.
 
 Point being, the quiz begins with assumptions about which I do not agree. It's logic is fine, as far as I can tell. It is not the logic of the quiz I have a problem with, it is the assumptions. If one starts with "incorrect" assumptions one gets to the wrong conclusion. If I start with the assumption that points have dimensions and are measurable, then my triangle will look very different.

directed to the religious people of the forum: 
 
 Is god omnipotent? (ie, are all things open to him to do, that is he can do anything.)
If you are asking that you need to define the word - and point out whether your version of omnipotence can actually include not being subject to definitions (i.e the square triangle thing).
well that is a good point, what- exactly, does omnipotence mean? We all say God is that- but we never ask what it is.

If you are asking that you need to define the word - and point out whether your version of omnipotence can actually include not being subject to definitions (i.e the square triangle thing).

 
 I think there was also another thread in the religious section that specifically dealt with that issue. I agree with Tasty, please define your terms.
 
 Also, please don't go with that old argument that if god can do anything then can he create a rock he cannot lift, if he can then he cannot do "anything." That one has been argued to death on another thread.
